text:
Broome Street, west from and including Columbia Street, showing the printing press factory of R. Hoe and Company on both sides of the street, between Columbia and Sheriff Streets. Both units were demolished, the one on the left is the site of a model apartment, and the other a playground; today 1937.

April 4, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, at a later date, showing construction work in progress for the "slum clearance" project. Governor Herbert Lehman was an active participant.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Broome Street, west from and including Columbia Street, showing the printing press factory of R. Hoe and Company on both sides of the street, between Columbia and Sheriff Streets. Both units were demolished, the one on the left is the site of a model apartment, and the other a playground; today 1937.

April 4, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, at a later date, showing construction work in progress for the "slum clearance" project. Governor Herbert Lehman was an active participant.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Columbia Street, west side, south from and including Broome Street, to and including Grand Street.
April 4, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Broome Street, from Sheriff to and including Columbia Street. The view also shows Sheriff Street, east side, from and including Broome to Delancey Streets.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

22 to 4 (left to right) Columbia Street, east side, south from Broome (left), to but not including Grand (right) Streets, showing construction work in progress on the west side of the street (the former site of the main plant of R. Hoe and Co., renowned printing press manufacturers) on a new apartment house. Included is a general view of the surrounding area, with the Williamsburg Bridge in the background.
June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Grand Street, north side, between Sheriff and Columbia Streets. (Street front not shown). Also shown is Broome Street north side, east from but not including Sheriff, to and including Columbia Streets. Included also is Columbia Street, east side, south from and including Broome, to, but not including Grand Streets. The view shows in the foreground, work in progress for the erection of a model apartment house on the site of the old R. Hoe and Company Plant, and in the background a portion of the Williamsburg Bridge.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, from a different angle, as No. 1 and showing Columbia Street, west side, north from and including Broome Street.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Grand Street, north side, between Sheriff and Columbia Streets. (Street front not shown). Also shown is Broome Street north side, east from but not including Sheriff, to and including Columbia Streets. Included also is Columbia Street, east side, south from and including Broome, to, but not including Grand Streets. The view shows in the foreground, work in progress for the erection of a model apartment house on the site of the old R. Hoe and Company Plant, and in the background a portion of the Williamsburg Bridge.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a closer view.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, from a different angle, as No. 1 and showing Columbia Street, west side, north from and including Broome Street.

June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Included also is Columbia Street, east side, south from and including Broome, to, but not including Grand Streets. The view shows in the foreground, work in progress for the erection of a model apartment house on the site of the old R. June 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Columbia Street, east side, from and including Broome Street to Williamsburg Bridge just south of Delancey Street.

October 12, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Grand Street Garage; Williamsburg Bridge: 3 Broome St.-Columbia St., Manhattan

text:
Broome Street, east from and including Columbia Street, to the East River. In the background, appears faintly, the Brooklyn shore.

March 26, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Broome Street (left), at the N.W. corner of Columbia (right) Street, showing a playground occupying the entire block from Columbia to Sheriff Streets, and from Broome to Delancey Streets. Also shown (left) is the 5-story annex building of R. Hoe and Co., renowned printing press Manufacturing firm, now occupied as a broom factory, and a portion of the Williamsburg Bridge (on Delancey Street).
March 26, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
